As we get things ready for the coming school year (new school, new schedule, new protocols for health and safety), we will give you little snapshots into our progress. They will totally be teases until we're ready to show the whole thing. Feel free to ask us questions, and we will do our best to answer, but keep in mind, we are in flux and may not have an answer yet!

First up, peeks at the blank canvases of Ms. Smith and Ms. Young's rooms. Note the retro technology that Mr. Petrecca said would be awesome for vintage gaming 🤣 (he has an original N64 for possible retro gaming Breakouts!).

Adriel gained both business skills and cosmetology practice at her iSEE partner, B. Anthony’s Salon. Adriel was enrolled in Auburn Career Center’s Cosmetology program, and found a great outlet for her interest in working for a salon through B. Anthony’s.

She initially sought to create and market a promotion for a manicure/pedicure service, and would then compare her results from the promotion against sales from previous years. She was unable to complete the promotion, because the salon closed in response to COVID 19.

However, Adriel said “it was great to get a look on the inside” of a salon, and learn “how to manage money for a business sustainably.” Her future plans include working for a salon, as well as entering the nursing program at Lakeland Community College!

Jonathon worked at Hearn Plumbing Heating & Air in Madison for his iSEE project. He transferred all written service records, which had previously been stored on Rolodexes, from 1990 on to a professional software database. He learned how to work with the details of the business, “identifying pieces of plumbing and HVAC equipment by their model and serial numbers.”

He also learned the personal interactions that go into small business practice. He was better able to “understand the web of connections between members of a company … [and] this experience has taught me to appreciate all of the work that goes into making businesses function well.”

His attention to detail and understanding of how people work together will serve him well as he heads on to Kent State University this fall to study History and Education!

For his iSEE, Cody worked on a unique collaboration with classmates Riley Weist and Jackson Senning to update computer networks at local Habitat for Humanity offices. Each office had different network standards and security protocols; Cody’s experience in Auburn Career Center's Mobile Applications & Technology program made him an ideal team member to address these problems.

Cody’s work at Habitat for Humanity gave him a new perspective on his future: “I’ve learned a lot about the career path I’m most interested in, broadening my interests more into the networking side than they were prior.” He plans to take a gap year after high school and then pursue a degree, hopefully at Bowling Green State University.

Faculty and staff celebrated Ms. Slivka yesterday for Administrative's Assistant Day with a beautiful video. While we won't show you the video (it did make Ms. Slivka tear up!), here is Ms. Smith's specially penned poem from it.

"Who sits at that round desk,
And says hello to all she sees?
Whose greetings are the kindest and warmest,
if you please?
Who knows just where to find
the pens, the markers, the coffee?
Who puts together all the things
in case of emergency?
Who carries the invisible weight
of keeping all in proper flow?
Who has been here since the start,
helping iSTEM always grow?
She is always willing to lend a hand,
or laugh with you and me.
Our one and only,
irreplaceable,
kind and funny
Glee."

We appreciate YOU, Ms. Slivka!

iSTEM students have joined together to fill the need for face shields for Lake Hospital and other health facilities in our area. The need was brought to our attention by GGP (Geauga Growth Partnership- Geauga County, Kimm Leininger), AWT (Alliance for Working Together - Lake County - Julianne Petti), and Lake Hospitals. Our incredibly innovative iSTEM students are keeping their 3-D Printers buzzing at home, producing a variety of face shields to meet the growing demand within the health systems that serve our communities. We currently have 8 students working towards filling this need. Each 3-D frame takes approximately 1 1/2 hours to create, with 20 minutes of further assembly. Every moment, every person counts. We are proud to say we are ......iSTEM STRONG!

Meet Dr. Falin!

Dr. Rebecca Falin has not been far from a lab since taking her first high school chemistry class. She got her first job working as a lab assistant a week after graduating high school and spent the next 17 years working as a technician and chemist at Avery-Dennison and Glastic Corporation. She earned Bachelor degrees in chemistry and physics from Cleveland State University by taking night classes before embarking on a mid-life quest for a doctorate, completing her PhD in biophysics at Case Western Reserve University in 2007. Following a postdoctoral fellowship at Vanderbilt University and Mount Desert Island Biological Lab, she taught chemistry and physics in rural West Virginia for five years. She returned home to Lake County in 2015 to be closer to her family.

In her free time, Dr. Falin enjoys hiking, gardening, growing clivias, unearthing family skeletons from the genealogical closet, and eating gummy worms.

You are able to move from teacher to teacher if desired. If additional time is needed with an individual teacher, you will have the opportunity to arrange a future conference.

They talked about the collaboration and having their voice heard.
